references: The frequently used notations are summarized in Table I.

As a result, no client except the source client knows the feature jğ‘—j and threshold vğ‘£v of the tree node split, since the lookup table is stored locally without sharing with any other clients. And when it turns to new instance prediction, the source client needs to combine with the split client to get the leaf value. For instance, as shown a simple decision tree in Fig. 5, client 111 is the source client of the root client and client 222 is its corresponding split client. If a new data sample with age 30 and weight 150 comes for prediction, it will be sent to client 111 for judgement. And then client 111 uses its own lookup table to determine that this instance should go to the left branch (30<35303530<35). After that, this data is sent to client 222 to get its label prediction 0.41 (150>120150120150>120, go to right leaf). Also considering potential label leakage during data prediction for ensemble decision trees, we adopt secure aggregation scheme proposed in [13] for secure multi-party computation. Therefore, the final prediction for the data instance can be derived without revealing any leaf values.

references: We partition each dataset into training data and test data. The training and test dataset occupies 80% and 20% of the entire data samples, respectively. Other experimental settings like the number of clients, the number of the maximum depth of the boosting tree are presented in Table II. Besides, each experiment is repeated for five times independently and the results of the mean values together with their standard deviations are plotted in the corresponding figures.

S5.T3.caption: TABLE III: Guess accuracy on different datasets
S5.T3.table:
Dataset Guess accuracy, no DP Guess accuracy, Ïµ=2italic-Ïµ2\epsilon=2 Guess accuracy, Ïµ=4italic-Ïµ4\epsilon=4 Guess accuracy, Ïµ=6italic-Ïµ6\epsilon=6 Guess accuracy, Ïµ=8italic-Ïµ8\epsilon=8 Guess accuracy, Ïµ=10italic-Ïµ10\epsilon=10
Credit card 68.75% 30.02% 23.02% 34.15% 27.78% 40.93%
Bank marketing 61.57% 39.57% 38.85% 25.85% 39.73% 14.45%
references:
For the sake of brevity, we calculate the expected guess accuracy of all participating clients with and without partial DP using different Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon values.
As shown in Table III, the guess accuracy is more than 60% for both two datasets without using partial DP, which is more accurate than a random guess.
After applying the proposed partial DP algorithm, however, the guess accuracies drop dramatically and are all less than 50%. Specifically on the Credit card dataset, the guess accuracy decreases to around 27% for Ïµ=10italic-Ïµ10\epsilon=10 and 45% for Ïµ=4italic-Ïµ4\epsilon=4. On the Bank marketing dataset, the guess accuracy drops to 14.45%percent\% when Ïµ=10italic-Ïµ10\epsilon=10. Since the noise in the DP follows the Gaussian distribution, it is normal that a smaller Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon values will give a higher guess accuracy. But as long as partial DP is used for label privacy protection, the guess accuracy is lower than a random guess, meaning that no label privacy is leaked from the received leaf outputs.
